thread.title: Servette 2-1 Chelsea: Post-Match Chelsea Player Ratings
thread.title_full: Servette 2-1 Chelsea: Post-Match Chelsea Player Ratings

author: Chance Chromik
title: Servette 2-1 Chelsea: Post-Match Chelsea Player Ratings
text:
Chelsea did not have as comfortable a night as they would have imagined going into the match, as they lost the Conference League Play-off second leg 2-1 to Servette.
Despite the late scare, the Blues still progress into the Conference League
Similar to the first leg, it was a
Christopher Nkunku penalty which opened the scoring on the night to make it 3-0 on aggregate.
Although it looked as if the tie would be over after that goal,
Servette did brilliantly to come back into the tie scoring a goal in each half to put pressure on the West Londoners late on.
Here is how each player performed:
Filip Jorgensen - 6
The Danish goalkeeper did not have as good a performance as he did in the first leg.
Although he made a couple of decent saves, he was poor on Servette's second goal of the match.
Axel Disasi - 5
Disasi was caught out of position for the first goal.
The French defender also did not look composed on the ball many times throughout the match.
Tosin Adarabioyo - 6
Adarabioyo was solid for large portions of the game and he does look composed playing out from the back.
However, he should have definitely done better for Servette's second.
Benoit Badiashile - 5
Very poor for the first goal as it looked as if he had switched off for a split second.
The Frenchman also does not fill you with confidence when he is on the ball.
Renato Veiga - 6
The Portuguese summer signing had a solid enough performance.
Although he was not perfect, you can tell that there is definitely a player in there and perhaps this was good business from Chelsea.
Enzo Fernandez - 6
He was controlling the match at times with his passing, but the final ball was lacking.
The Argentine does not offer enough defensively though, as many times he was ran past too easily.
Kiernan Dewsbury-Hall - 5
The midfielder picked up some good positions at times but he lost the ball too often.
The former
Leicester City man's final ball also was not there.
https://www.vavel.com/en/football/2024/08/01/chelsea-fc/1190781-enzo-maresca-very-happy-after-improved-chelsea-performance-in-atlanta.html - 7
As he did in the first leg, Nkunku scored the penalty for the Blues.
The Frenchman also looked like a creative threat throughout the match, and was unlucky to not get another goal or assist.
Noni Madueke - 6
Madueke looked dangerous at times cutting in on the right.
However, the final product was not there as it was against
Wolves on the weekend.
Mykhailo Mudryk - 6
It was a performance that we are used to seeing from the Ukrainian, bright moments and electric pace but no end product.
He did win the penalty for his side and did look better overall than he did in the first leg.
Marc Guiu - 5
The young Spanish striker pressed well as he did in the first leg.
However, other than that he struggled to lead the line and did not have the best of matches.
-
Substitutes
Tyrique George - 7
The young winger grew into the game the longer he was on the pitch.
A creative threat, it looks as if Cobham has another gem on their hands.
Moises Caicedo - 6
Caicedo came on for Enzo and added a bit more durability than his Argentinian counterpart would have done.
It was not a performance to write home about, but he was alright.
Nicolas Jackson - 7
The Senegalese forward came on and definitely was a threat.
He put the ball in the back of the net, but it was ruled out for offside.
Jackson will be leaving this match wondering how he did not get a goal or an assist.
Cole Palmer - 7
Similar to Jackson, the Englishman will be wondering how he did not leave this game with a goal.
Palmer hit the woodwork and also linked well with his teammates in a creative showing off the bench.
